results.title: Diabetes, Metformin and the Clinical Course of Covid-19: Outcomes, Mechanisms and Suggestions on the Therapeutic Use of Metformin
results.text_hl: Conclusion: The pleiotropic actions of @<m>CHEMICAL_Metformin</m> @CHEMICAL_MESH:D008687 @@@metformin@@@ associated with lower background cardiovascular risk may mediate some of these effects, for example reductions of @DISEASE_Insulin_Resistance @DISEASE_MESH:D007333 @@@insulin resistance@@@, systemic @DISEASE_Inflammation @DISEASE_MESH:D007249 @@@inflammation@@@ and @<m>DISEASE_Thrombophilia</m> @DISEASE_MESH:D019851 @@@hypercoagulability@@@.

citations.NLM: Bailey CJ, Gwilt M. Diabetes, Metformin and the Clinical Course of Covid-19: Outcomes, Mechanisms and Suggestions on the Therapeutic Use of Metformin Front Pharmacol. 2022;13():784459. PMID: 35370738
citations.BibTeX: @article{35370738, title={Diabetes, Metformin and the Clinical Course of Covid-19: Outcomes, Mechanisms and Suggestions on the Therapeutic Use of Metformin}, author={Bailey CJ and Gwilt M}, journal={Front Pharmacol}, volume={13}, pages={784459}}

results.title: High Dose of Metformin Decreases Susceptibility to Occlusive Arterial Thrombosis in Diabetic Mice
results.text_hl: High doses of @<m>CHEMICAL_Metformin</m> @CHEMICAL_MESH:D008687 @@@Metformin@@@ have also been associated with @<m>DISEASE_Thrombophilia</m> @DISEASE_MESH:D019851 @@@hypercoagulation@@@.

results.title: Metformin use in patients hospitalized with COVID-19: lower inflammation, oxidative stress, and thrombotic risk markers and better clinical outcomes
results.text_hl: Our aim was to explore the effects of @<m>CHEMICAL_Metformin</m> @CHEMICAL_MESH:D008687 @@@metformin@@@ on markers of @DISEASE_Inflammation @DISEASE_MESH:D007249 @@@inflammation@@@, oxidative stress, and @<m>DISEASE_Thrombophilia</m> @DISEASE_MESH:D019851 @@@hypercoagulability@@@, and on clinical outcomes.

citations.NLM: Usman A, Bliden KP, Cho A, Walia N, Jerjian C, Singh A, Kundan P, Duhan S, Tantry US, Gurbel PA. Metformin use in patients hospitalized with COVID-19: lower inflammation, oxidative stress, and thrombotic risk markers and better clinical outcomes J Thromb Thrombolysis. 2022 Feb;53(2):363-371. PMID: 35041121
